items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Preliminary Budget for 2016-2017
	 
	 
Attached for your review is a presentation of the 2016-17 Preliminary Budget. This is the second of four presentations of the Budget to the Governing Board.  The Preliminary Budget is the result of a culmination of budget development activities between the sites, departments, and Superintendent’s Council which provides a basis for the final budget.  The Preliminary Budget Presentation is summarized first by providing an update on the District’s fiscal year ending 2015-16 budget, State budget update, and preliminary assumptions.  The fiscal year 2015-16 budget is presented to provide year end projections for revenues, expenses, and ending fund balance.  After reviewing the fiscal year end 2015-16 summary, major budget assumptions for developing the 2016-17 budget will be discussed including School Services of California Dartboard, enrollment and ADA, and salaries and benefits.  The impact and adjustments based on the Governor’s May Revisions have not been announced yet and will be presented at the first Governing Board Meeting in June.  
	 
The Preliminary Budget Presentation summarizes the projected estimate for general fund revenues and expenses for budget year 2016-17 and for the multi-year through 2018-19 and incorporates all proposed savings, additions and adjustments to the District’s budget.  The presentation concludes with a summary of proposed actions and next steps in the budget process.  The final budget will be presented for budget adoption at the Governing Board’s June 23rd meeting.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Information only.
items.item_recommendation: Information only.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent, and Dale Scott, Dale Scott & Company
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion, Consideration, and/or Action to regarding Ordering an Election for Parcel Tax or the Issuance of School Bonds Occurring on the November 8, 2016, Presidential Primary Election
	 
At the April 21, 2016, Board Meeting, Dale Scott presented the polling results for a potential authorization for a new General Obligation (GO) bond and/or a parcel tax to be placed on the November 2016 presidential primary election ballot.  The results of the polling favored pursuing a GO bond versus pursing a parcel tax. 
	 
Tonight, Dale Scott is back to share more information on pursing both the GO Bond and parcel tax.  He will be sharing information regarding:
	 
1.  History of parcel tax elections for ESUHSD
2.  History of feeder district elections
3.  Additional review of polling. Possible issues as to why GO bond yes vote moved, but parcel tax did not.
	 
Staff is seeking direction from the Board of Trustees as to the type of resolution staff should bring back to the Board at either the June 9th or June 23rd Board meeting in support of pursuing a GO bond or parcel tax.
	 
	 
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration is seeking direction from the Board of Trustees as to the type of resolution staff should bring back to the Board at either the June 9th or June 23rd Board meeting in support of pursuing a GO bond or parcel tax.

SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:45 p.m. Disclosure of Major Provisions of Proposed Tentative Agreement with California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, July 1, 2016 - June 30, 2019 (Per AB 1200); Discussion and/or Action
	 
	 
In accordance with Assembly Bill 1200 requiring school districts to disclose, at a public meeting, the cost that would be incurred by the implementation of a collective bargaining agreement.  In meeting the requirement, a public hearing is being held to give our community an opportunity to comment on the cost of this tentative agreement.
	Attached is a copy of the proposed changes to the collective bargaining agreement with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187.   The District and the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, reached a tentative agreement on April 27, 2016.  The tentative agreement was ratified by the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187 on May 11, 2016.
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept any comment on the proposed tentative agreement with the California School Employees Association, Chapter 187, July 1, 2016 - June 30, 2019.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Pattie Cortese, Board Member, Frank Biehl, Board Vice President, and
Mariel Caballero, CBOC Chairperson
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Consideration and/or Action regarding the Selection/Appointment
of Measures G, E, I and Ed-Tech I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee Members
	 
	 
Pursuant to Section 15278 of the Education Code, the District is obligated to establish a Citizens’ Bond Oversight Committee (CBOC) in order to satisfy the accountability requirements of Proposition 39 type general obligation bonds. The Committee is required to consist of a minimum of seven (7) members appointed by the Board of Trustees.
	 
As explained in the terms of Proposition 39, the CBOC is required to have members that meet the criteria listed below:
	 
One (1) member shall be active in a business organization representing the business community located within the District
One (1) member shall be active in a senior citizens’ organization
One (1) member shall be active in a bona fide taxpayers’ organization
One (1) member shall be the parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the district
One (1) member shall be both a parent or guardian of a child enrolled in the District and be active in a parent-teacher organization, such as the Parent-Teacher Association or the School Site Council
Two (2) members of the community at-large
	 
No employees or officials of the District can be appointed to the CBOC.  Also vendors, contractors, or consultants of the District are not allowed to serve as members of the Committee.
	 
Under the current bylaws of the CBOC, members are allowed to serve three (3) consecutive two (2) year terms. To allow for history and consistency, terms are staggered to avoid all members terming out at the same time.
	 
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees appoint the following individuals to serve on the 2016/2017 Measures G, E and I and Ed-Tech I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee:

Since the Board did not receive any applications to fill the required position of a member active in a bona fide taxpayers’ organization, recruitment will continue and will be presented to the Board for recommendation/consideration at a future Board Meeting.  The Silicon Valley Taxpayers’ Association and the California Taxpayers’ Association will be asked to assist in recruiting a member to serve in this capacity.
	 
The Board would like to thank the following community members for serving on the CBOC.  These individuals have either served the maximum three terms or elected not to reapply due to other obligations:
Andres Quintero
Joshua Barousse
Timothy Tom

RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees appoint the following, with specified role designations, as members of the Measures G, E, I and Ed-Tech I Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee for two-year terms starting July 1, 2016, through June 30, 2018:
Parent / guardian of a child in the district:  Brad Geldert;
Active in a business organization:  Bud Lomonaco;
Members of the community at large:  Rajesh Godbole; Barry Schimmel and Vince Tran.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Glenn Vander Zee, Assistant Superintendent of Educational Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Assessment & Accountability
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action on Academic Success Analysis
	 
This presentation shows updated data on the progress of the F rates in the High F rate courses outlined in 2013-14 and 2014-15.  Those courses are Biology, English 1, Basic English 1, World History, Integrated Science, Geometry, and Genres.  Algebra 1 was originally discussed in 2013-14, however, with the transition to common core the District no longer offers Algebra 1 but offers CCSS Math 1 as the first level math course instead.  The District is phasing out Geometry and is replacing the second year math course with CCSS Math 2.  Grade distributions for CCSS Math 1 and CCSS Math 2 are displayed.
	 
The analysis of this presentation focuses on the following concerns:
Are we seeing a reduction in F rates in target courses?
F rate shifts across ethnicities
Which courses do we need to focus efforts to improve student outcomes?
Is there a difference in performance between on grade level students and others?
2 year change in A-G course completion in targeted courses
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the presentation as presented.

SUBJECT:
Presentation and Discussion regarding the Child Nutrition Services Food Vending Program and Meal Pricing Recommendations
	 
	 
East Side Union High School District has been under considerable financial pressure over the past 3 years in relation to increased State and Federal mandates.  The district has also negotiated salary increases that must now be recognized in the Child Nutrition Services budget.  Student breakfast and adult lunch prices were increased $.25 in 2014-15.  It is our recommendation to increase student lunch prices from $3.00 to $3.25 and adult breakfast prices from $2.00 to $2.50 beginning July 1, 2016.  The fiscal impact to the Child Nutrition Services budget would be $8,912 in additional revenue.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
AMENDED
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to approve Charter School Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreement with ACE Charter High School
	 
	 
On or before November 1, 2015, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2016-2017 school year from ACE Charter High School (“ACE”).  ACE currently operates its charter program at the District’s Independence High School campus, and its current facility use agreement with the District expires June 30, 2016.  ACE, like most of the District’s charter schools, is allocated facilities on a yearly basis by the District. 
	 
This year, instead of adhering to the timelines for facilities allocation under the Proposition 39 and its implementing regulations, the District and ACE agreed to enter into a modified process to review ACE’s facilities request and needs, discuss an allocation of Prop. 39 facilities to ACE that meets ACE’s needs and the District’s available facilities resources, and consider a multi-year facilities use agreement which would allow the District and ACE to better plan and facilitate charter school programs and uses on District sites.
	 
The Administration desires to house ACE in Buildings G and Building H at Independence High School Site. The District intends to modernize those facilities at the as part of its capital building program, the cost of which to the District is estimated at $3,688,000.00.  ACE desires and has identified additional building improvements to Buildings G and H to accommodate ACE’s instructional and education program needs (the “Additional Improvements”).  The District and ACE have determined that the total additional cost of constructing the Additional Improvements is $1,383,000.00 (the “Additional Improvements Cost Amount”).  ACE is e room, theater, parking, athletic fields) to be used in connection with ACE’s academic and athletic program, and for no other purpose.
	 
If (1) ACE defaults and is dispossessed of the Premises, or (b) if ACE voluntarily leaves the premises because ACE determines that it no longer can operate its school in the premises, (3) and in each case provided that ACE has not proposed a Subtenant for the Premises which has been accepted or rejected by the District, then, provided further that ACE is not in breach or default under the PRI Loan agreements, the District agrees to assume repayment of the remaining unpaid original principal balance only under the PRI Loan agreements, not including interest, costs, fees or any other charges, for the remaining repayment term under the PRI Loan, subject to the District’s right to prepay without penalty, and subject to ACE’s duty to indemnify District in regard to any skipped or missed monthly payments up to the time of dispossession.
	 
In connection with this proposed arrangement, ACE will make a $80,000 cash security deposit with the District.  The deposit is intended to mitigate the District’s risk in having to assume the repayment of the principal of the PRI loan as outlined above.  Beginning in year 6 of the agreement and provided that ACE is then current on its payments of the PRI Loan, the security deposit shall be reduced in increments of $5,000.00 on the first day of each of Years Six through Ten, and thereafter the balance of the Security Deposit shall be reduced to zero and credited to ACE on the first day of Year Eleven of the Term hereof.  This last reduction shall be conditioned on ACE having completed its payments and retired the PRI Loan.
	 
The Administration requests authority to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement containing these terms in accordance with the District’s modified form Facilities Use Agreement (copy attached).
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To be determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement containing these terms in accordance with the District's modified Facilities Use Agreement (copy attached).

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to approve Charter School Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreement with Summit Public School: Rainier Charter School 
	 
	 
On or before November 1, 2015, the District received a request for reasonably equivalent facilities for the 2016-2017 school year from Summit Public School – Rainier Charter High School (“Rainier”).  Rainier currently operates its charter program at the District’s Mt. Pleasant campus, and its current facility use agreement with the District expires June 30, 2016.  Rainier, like most of the District’s charter schools, is allocated facilities on a yearly basis by the District. 
	 
This year, instead of adhering to the timelines for facilities allocation under the Proposition 39 and its implementing regulations, the District and Rainier agreed to enter into a modified process to review Rainier’s facilities request and needs, discuss an allocation of Prop, 39 facilities to Rainier that meets Rainier’s needs and the District’s available resources, and consider a 3-5 year facilities use agreement which would allow the District and Rainier to better plan and facilitate charter school programs and uses on District sites.
	 
The District and Rainier have now reached agreement for continued Prop. 39 facilities for Rainier at Mt. Pleasant High School.  Administration proposes a five (5) year facility use agreement for Rainier at the Mt. Pleasant site for the term July 1, 2016 – June 30, 2021.  The agreement is conditioned upon Rainier maintaining its charter in good standing and Rainier continuing to pay its pro rata share of facilities costs as authorized by Prop. 39.  The facilities include both “Dedicated Space” (classroom and administrative facilities for Rainier’s exclusive use in connection with its education program) and equitable shared use of other site facilities (including, for example, gyms, multi-purpose room, theatre, parking, athletic fields) to be used in connection with Rainier’s academic and athletic program, and for no other purpose.
	 
The Administration requests authority to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement with Rainier for a five (5) year term in accordance with the District’s form Facilities Use Agreement (copy attached) subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement for charter school facilities with Rainier for a five (5) year term at the Mt. Pleasant High School site in accordance with with the District's form Facilities Use Agreement and subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize Administration to negotiate and enter into a Facilities Use Agreement for charter school facilities with Rainier for a five (5) year term at the Mt. Pleasant High School site in accordance with with the District's form Facilities Use Agreement and subject to subsequent ratification by the Board.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Receive Update on request to approve authorization for the Superintendent or Designee to award the contract needed for the Yerba Buena Alternative Education Mini-Campus Improvements
	 
	 
On April 21, 2016 (Board Item 15.04), the Board received a request to approve authorization for the Superintendent or Designee to award the contract needed for the Yerba Buena Alternative Education Mini-Campus Improvements – LVLA Project (E-060-008) – Bid # B-06-15-16.  All work awarded under this action was to be brought to the Board for ratification at the scheduled May 19, 2016, Board meeting.
Bids for the Project were received on Wednesday, May 4, 2016. The District only received (1) one bid for the project. After reviewing the bid package it was considered a responsive and complete bid. The Engineer’s estimate for the scope of work is $1,400,000.00 with the scope being within budget. The single bid received from Strawn Construction was for $2,754,000.00. The single bid received is $1,354,000.00 over budget.
	 
On Thursday, May 5, 2016 the Business Office in conjunction with Facilities Staff contacted both YBHS and LVLA to discuss the bid developments. With regard to LVLA the District recognized that there are (13) thirteen portable buildings currently on site, and for the 2016/17 school year LVLA was offered (12) twelve portables per the agreement approved by the Board on April 21, 2016 – Charter School Proposition 39 Facilities Use Agreement with Luis Valdez Leadership Academy Charter High School (Board Item 13.04).  The District assured LVLA that they would have access to the existing (12) twelve portables in their current configuration at the Yerba Buena campus for the 2016/17 school year.
	 
The District accepts the Construction Manager’s recommendation to reject the bids and rebid the Project.  The District is working on a strategy to re-bid the project and implement the improvements at the next available opportunity.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees rejects the bid received from Strawn Construction and approves staff to rebid the project.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees rejects the bid received from Strawn Construction and approves staff to rebid the project.

PREPARED BY:

SUBJECT:
Approve Student Names for the Go-For-It Scholarship Recipients
	 
Administration is requesting approval to award $32,000.00 for the "Go For It" Scholarship Fund to East Side Union High School Students.
	 
Silicon Valley Community Foundation requires authorization to release and distribute funds upon receiving required documentation from recipients.
	 
The District in the early 1990's, invested an initial $500,000.00 in revenues into the "Go For It" fund and collected several hundred thousand dollars from the private sector to create annual interest revenues to fund scholarships.
	 
The investment fund had not performed well during the economic downturn, but recently it has recovered and the District can resume awarding scholarships.  We recommend issuing 16 scholarships worth $2,000.00 each totaling $32,000.00.
	 
Attached are the lists of recipients to receive the Scholarship funds.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A

N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:

PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, André Bell, Director of Purchasing and Capital Accounting, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
								 
								 
SUBJECT:
Ratification of Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services At or Below $50,000  
					 
					 
The attached lists the Bond/Capital Projects Contracts for Professional Services at or below $50,000 being recommended for Board ratification. 
					 
Fiscal Impact:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Funding Source:
As indicated in the attachment
					 
Recommendation:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees ratify the Bond/Capital Projects Contract(s) for Professional Services at or below $50,000 as recommended in the attachment and authorization is being requested for the Superintendent and/or designee to execute amendments to the Agreement that may be needed during the term, provided such amendments do not: (i) extend the term of the contract; (ii) increase the price of goods or services provided under the contract by the greater of ten percent (10%) of the contract amount (based on the original contract amount exclusive of any approved amendments in the aggregate); or (iii) alter the quality or quantity of services or goods provided under the Board-approved contract per Board Policy 3312.1.

SUBJECT:
Capital Program Budget Adjustment Report   
			 
			 
Attached for your review is the Capital Program Budget Adjustment Report.  This report was created as a result of the audit finding by Moss Adams LLP during the latest performance audit for Fiscal Year ending June 30, 2014, and June 30, 2015.  In an effort to improve effectiveness of the communication channels among all stakeholders within the Bond Program, this new Capital Budget Program Adjustment Report will list any new changes to a project budget within the month.
